40830345542249.name: Masterclass - H15 - Shading | Kai Stavginski

41073181659237.author: Jeff Lait
41073181659237.description: New Planar Patch from Curve tools in Houdini 17 open the possibility for simple tailoring.   This masterclass goes over the process of designing a dress for Tommy, showing how the Vellum Drape node can be used to build clothing panel-by-panel.
41073181659237.name: Masterclass - H17 - Vellum Drape | Jeff Lait

42236171267116.author: John Lynch
42236171267116.description: This masterclass will cover new Vellum constraint features in Houdini 18, some of which are workflow enhancements. This includes automatically computing mass and thickness based on density, making it easier to work with geometry of different resolutions. Normalizing stress computations over substeps, will save you the hassle of having to adjust threshold values when changing substeps. For the new constraint features, there are Stiffness Dropoff, Tangent Stiffness, Stitch to primitive location, Sliding for Stitch and Attach constraints, and ARAP constraints which are effective for simulating organic material/softbody and things that require good stretching and compression behaviour.
42236171267116.name: Masterclass - H18 - Vellum Constraint Features | John Lynch

43079209841331.author: Jeff Lait
43079209841331.description: In this masterclass, we step through the functions of attribute paint.  We also briefly unpack it and look at how it can be embedded as a tool in other assets.
43079209841331.name: Masterclass - H18 - Attribute Paint | Jeff Lait

4472965976985.author: Jeff Lait
4472965976985.description: Houdini 17's new Vellum solver provides exciting new multi-physics possibilities.  This masterclass provides an overview of the available solvers; and addresses both their SOP and DOP incarnations.
4472965976985.name: Masterclass - H17 - Vellum Overview | Jeff Lait

44834025197449.author: Matt Estela
44834025197449.description: A 20 day program, each day aiming to be between 5 and 30 minutes plus exercises.
44834025197449.name: cgwiki - Joy of Vex

49417444168066.author: John Lynch
49417444168066.description: The Vellum Solver in Houdini provides many features for interesting effects such as sticky collisions, tearing, deformable solids, and permanent bending from plastic flow. This masterclass provides an overview of the inner workings of the Vellum Solver, then describes its use in such effects, covering topics such as graph coloring, animated constraint properties, dynamic constraints, plasticity, and soft bodies.
49417444168066.name: Masterclass - H17 - Advanced Vellum Workflows | John Lynch

5473943102581.author: Omar Zarifi
5473943102581.description: This masterclass covers features of the redesigned whitewater system in Houdini 17. It starts with an overview of the major changes to the system. The new workflow is then demonstrated by adding whitewater to several simple scenarios.
5473943102581.name: Masterclass - H17 - Whitewater System | Omar Zarifi

56186690260330.author: Mark Davies
56186690260330.description: Houdini 15 introduces many enhancements to the Mantra renderer, adding exciting new features and building on existing strengths. New features include quality metrics, adaptive sampling, texture & surface baking and render check-pointing. This class provides a mix of the theory behind the new features and practical techniques to help get you started using them in production.
56186690260330.name: Masterclass - H15 - Mantra Rendering & Texture Baking | Mark Davies

56186690260331.author: Jeff Lait
56186690260331.description: Houdini's grain solver uses Position Based Dynamics to simulate sand. This masterclass describes what that means and re-builds the sand solver from microsolvers. It also provides some insight and advice in how to tweak the grain solver's parameters to get the effects you desire.
56186690260331.name: Masterclass - H15 - Grains | Jeff Lait

56186690260332.author: John Lynch
56186690260332.description: In recent releases, advances in Houdini's FLIP solver and distribution capabilities have enabled very large scale liquid simulations. However, the data sets produced by such large simulations can be unwieldy to save to disk and produce renderable surface meshes and secondary elements. This Houdini 15 Masterclass describes production-oriented additions to the Houdini FLIP toolset that provide compression of large FLIP simulations for optimized post-simulation workflows, including surfacing and whitewater. We also examine the new ParticleFluidSurface::2.0 surfacing asset and shading features, as well as improvements to the FLIP solver velocity transfer and the new Viscous Fluid shelf tools.
56186690260332.name: Masterclass - H15 - FLIP Workflow Enhancements | John Lynch

56186690260333.author: Jeff Lait
56186690260333.description: Houdini has supported distributed solvers since Houdini 10. This masterclass provides an overview of the current state of these solvers; including the new support for resizing smoke simulations and water tanks in Houdini 15. The first half demonstrates the setup of a variety of distributed effects using shelf tools and HQueue. The final bit dives into technicality and builds a new distributed setup via microsolvers and manually invokes the tracker.
56186690260333.name: Masterclass - H15 - Distributed Simulations | Jeff Lait

56186690260334.author: Cameron White
56186690260334.description: This masterclass provides an overview of several new features and improvements for crowd simulations in Houdini 15. This includes: tools for creating additional layers for an agent, ragdoll simulations, material stylesheets, and many workflow improvements.
56186690260334.name: Masterclass - H15 - Crowds | Cameron White

56186690260335.author: Mark Tucker
56186690260335.description: Material Style Sheets provide a powerful and flexible new way to assign Mantra materials and overrides. This masterclass provides detailed explanations of how to use Style Sheets to describe looks for objects, geometry, packed primitives, and crowds. It also covers the use of VEX scripting to procedurally override parameters at render time based on geometry attributes.
56186690260335.name: Masterclass - H15 - Material Style Sheets | Mark Tucker

56186690260336.author: Pavlo Penenko
56186690260336.description: This masterclass decribes a new RPC feature introduced in Houdini Engine 2.0, called Thin Client. Thin Client extends the reach of Houdini Engine by moving Houdini simulations to a separate server process and helps to solve dependency problems, utilize multiple concurrent Houdini simulations, distribute computations on the network and integrate Houdini Engine with hosts on a wider variety of plaforms.
56186690260336.name: Masterclass - H15 - Thin Client | Pavlo Penenko

56186690260337.author: Cameron White
56186690260337.description: This masterclass provides an overview of several new features and improvements for crowd simulations in Houdini 15.5. This includes: new versions of the crowd DOP nodes, foot locking, improvements to locomotion and terrain adaptation, and advanced controls for transitions between animation clips.
56186690260337.name: Masterclass - H15.5 - Crowds Update | Cameron White

56186690260338.author: Jeff Lait
56186690260338.description: Houdini 16's new terrain tools are built on heightfields. Heightfields in Houdini are groups of 2D volumes displayed in the viewport and at render time, as a distorted grid. In this masterclass, we delve into what these are, and how you can use them beyond terrains.
56186690260338.name: Masterclass - H16 - Terrains - Heightfields | Jeff Lait

56186690260339.author: Jeff Lait
56186690260339.description: New in Houdini 16 is the ability to block-off a group of nodes to be compiled. This unlocks the ability to multithread for-each loops, but requires some attention to detail. This masterclass runs through the do-s and don't-s of compiled SOPs.
56186690260339.name: Masterclass - H16 - Compiled SOPs | Jeff Lait

56186690260340.author: Kai Stavginski
56186690260340.description: This masterclass covers new shading features in Houdini 16. The focus is on aspects that enable visual effects which weren't possible before. For example realistic absorption and dispersion. Nested dielectrics are covered in depth. These allow for correct rendering of interfaces between transparent media with hardly any setup work. Scene files are available for download below.
56186690260340.name: Masterclass - H16 - New Shading Features | Kai Stavginski

56186690260341.author: John Mariella
56186690260341.description: Muscles in Houdini are versatile, easy to use, interconnected tools. Houdini's muscle system has been designed to serve both FEM (dynamics simulations) and non-FEM (skin deformer) workflows while using a unified set of digital assets. With the foundational information presented in this video, you'll be ready to rig up a creature with simple muscles and you'll be prepared to take the next steps: creating custom muscles, and using muscles in simulations with Houdini's Tissue System.
56186690260341.name: Masterclass - H16 - Muscles Overview | John Mariella

56186690260342.author: Kai Stavginski
56186690260342.description: Houdini 16 moves shading and shader building into a new unified context called Material Networks. This masterclass by Kai Stavginski goes over everything you need to use the new context and build custom shaders in it. The result is a Custom Shader with the outputs required for mixing with built-in shaders, where you can blend individual shaders for specific results (displacements, roughness, metallic, etc.). Kai demonstrates the difference between Principled Shader and Principled Shader Core, the Classic Shader and benefit of cached code. Towards the end of the masterclass, Kai also explains OpenGL tags to visualize shaders in the viewport.
56186690260342.name: Masterclass - H16 - Custom Shading | Kai Stavginski

56186690260343.author: Michael Goldfarb
56186690260343.description: Houdini 16 includes the new modular Autorigs system. This masterclass provides an introduction to the tools and demonstrates a complete workflow starting with an imported character mesh all the way to a Digital Asset that is ready for animation.
56186690260343.name: Masterclass - H16 - Autorig Tools Overview | Michael Goldfarb

56186690260344.author: Ryan Goldade
56186690260344.description: We have added some exciting new features to the Flip Fluid simulation in Houdini 16. We now provide better control of the simulation through the waterline, boundary layer and variable slip viscosity features. We are also able to create new and interesting fluid behaviour with our surface tension and suction fluid effects. In this masterclass we show how to reduce reflecting waves with the waterline and boundary layer tools and how the boundary layer can be extended to river upressing. We show demonstrate new effects like creating a crown splash and directable fluid to fill a character and how sliding viscous fluid can create more believable behaviour.
56186690260344.name: Masterclass - H16 - Flip Fluids | Ryan Goldade

56186690260345.author: Kai Stavginski
56186690260345.description: Houdini 16 comes with a redesigned set of Fur and Hair tools. This masterclass introduces the new workflow and techniques from the ground up. We look at the structure and overall design of fur object node, a new set of procedural SOP tools, dynamics and rendering. We also show how the general power and flexibility of SOPs can be used to design fur and hair styles.
56186690260345.name: Masterclass - H16 - Hair and Fur | Kai Stavginski

56186690260346.author: John Lynch
56186690260346.description: Houdini's Ocean tools have been significantly redesigned for Houdini 16, offering more control over the look and timing of oceans, render-time evaluation of ocean spectra, and improved tools for integration with FLIP simulations. This masterclass starts by examining the meaning of an ocean 'spectrum', then explores the new additions in Houdini 16 and how they can create 'infinite' oceans with particle-based foam, as well as embedded FLIP simulations using an Extended Surface workflow.
56186690260346.name: Masterclass - H16 - Ocean | John Lynch

63398642516243.author: cnc via facebook
63398642516243.description: Creates a yin and yang logo
63398642516243.name: Yin & Yang Logo

56186690260350.author: Jeff Lait
56186690260350.description: Details on using vellum for Cloth. This masterclass covers techniques for using Vellum with cloth. It covers re-starting sims from drapes, wedging, painting pins, targeting low res sims, reference frames, 2nd order integration, collision disabling, layer shock, and using vellum to fix model geometry.
56186690260350.name: Masterclass - H17 - Vellum Cloth | Jeff Lait

56186690260351.author: Cameron White
56186690260351.description: Cameron begins with constraints - particularly, soft constraints, along with some useful new options in Glue Constraint.  He continues with SOPs - Convex Decomposition - as well as some useful utility SOPs like Extract Centroid, Extract Transform, and new options for Attribute Promote when working with RBD objects.  The last topic will be the new Fracturing tools, including Voronoi Fracture 2.0, new Boolean Fracture SOP, and the higher-level RBD Material Fracture toolset introduced in the latest release.
56186690260351.name: Masterclass - H17 - RBD Tools Update | Cameron White

56186690260353.author: Jeff Lait
56186690260353.description: The OpenCL SOP and DOP allow you to take advantage of your GPU to do computations. This Masterclass walks through how to use the OpenCL SOP. It also addresses when you should use OpenCL, and when you should use VEX.
56186690260353.name: Masterclass - H16.5 - OpenCL vs Vex | Jeff Lait

56186690260354.author: Michael Goldfarb
56186690260354.description: This is an introductory video on rigging in Houdini, which will go over rigging as an overview, HDAs, objects vs geometry, parenting and hierarchies, bones and nulls, animation controls, constraints, rotation order/gimbal lock, naming conventions, mirroring and rigging, and animation scripts.
56186690260354.name: Masterclass - H16.5 - Rigging Series Intro | Michael Goldfarb

56186690260355.author: Michael Goldfarb
56186690260355.description: In Part 1, we will create an HDA and start working on the spine. We will be using the Path Tool, Bones Tool, Follow Curve IK; we will create controls, create proxy geo and create HDA parameters.
56186690260355.name: Masterclass - H16.5 - Rigging Series I - HDA, Spine | Michael Goldfarb

56186690260356.author: Michael Goldfarb
56186690260356.description: In Part 2, we will work on the Neck, Head and Eyes. We will add 'space switching' to the Head and Eyes using constraints.
56186690260356.name: Masterclass - H16.5 - Rigging Series II - Head, Eyes, Neck | Michael Goldfarb

56186690260357.author: Michael Goldfarb
56186690260357.description: In Part 3, we will begin rigging the Left Arm. The arm will have both Forward and Inverse Kinematics, the ability to twist both the upper and lower arm as well as 'space switching' for the wrist.
56186690260357.name: Masterclass - H16.5 - Rigging Series III - Left Arm | Michael Goldfarb

56186690260358.author: Michael Goldfarb
56186690260358.description: In Part 4 we will rig the Left Hand and complete the Left Arm. The Hand will have global and individual controls for finger curl, splay, fan and flex. The Left Arm and Hand will be mirrored to the Right side. We will finish the Left and Right Arms by adding the twist for both upper and lower arm bones, and add some optional automatic controls to drive the shoulder.
56186690260358.name: Masterclass - H16.5 - Rigging Series IV - Left Hand & Left Arm Completion | Michael Goldfarb

10383418825313.author: Matt Estela
10383418825313.description: Kinefx covers a lot of ground, but there's a pleasing DNA share with a lot of established houdini workflows. Basically if you've used packed prims before and wrangles, you get the core of kinefx.
10383418825313.name: cgwiki - KineFX | Matt Estela

10383418825314.author: Matt Estela
10383418825314.description: A Houdini Digital Asset (HDA) is like a maya reference. You export a chunk of a hip to an external file (eg c:/projects/library/coolthing.hda), now those nodes live somewhere else on disk, and you can bring them into your hip like a reference.
10383418825314.name: cgwiki - Digital Assets | Matt Estela

10383418825315.author: Matt Estela
10383418825315.description: Tops is a node graph for tasks and processes. It's similar to Rops in that it lets you chain operations together and control execution order. A major difference between Rops and Tops is fine grain control. Layering analogies, Rops compared to Tops is like /obj compared to Sops.
10383418825315.name: cgwiki - Tops / PDG | Matt Estela

10383418825316.author: Matt Estela
10383418825316.description: Remember a python sop is like a wrangle, only obtuse.
10383418825316.name: cgwiki - Python | Matt Estela

10383418825317.author: Matt Estela
10383418825317.description: There's probably other quick mantra light/shade/render overviews, but I couldn't find any, at least not in the impatient 5 mins or less category that I require. This is my usual kick-the-tyres process I do for any new renderer, thought other curious lighter/shader folk would find it interesting.
10383418825317.name: cgwiki - Lighting and Shading | Matt Estela

10383418825318.author: Matt Estela
10383418825318.description: Some useful tips for the Houdini UI
10383418825318.name: cgwiki - UI Tips | Matt Estela

10383418825321.author: Matt Estela
10383418825321.description: Cops is Houdini's built in compositing network. In theory its powerful, but in practice its one of the older systems within Houdini and needs some love. If you're in the market for an unstable and slow compositor, Cops has you covered.
10383418825321.name: cgwiki - Cops (Compositing) | Matt Estela

10383418825322.author: Matt Estela
10383418825322.description: The standard analogy is 'audio processing', but there's a few other things chops does, handy to be aware of them all.
10383418825322.name: cgwiki - Chops | Matt Estela

10383418825323.author: Matt Estela
10383418825323.description: Vops are a node based shading network, but as well as describing surfaces, they can also deform, create and destroy geometry
10383418825323.name: cgwiki - Vops | Matt Estela

10383418825324.author: Matt Estela
10383418825324.name: cgwiki - Lops / Solaris / USD | Matt Estela

10383418825325.author: Matt Estela
10383418825325.description: So, you have a character mesh, and you want to generate hair. The workflow is to generate low-res guides, groom the guides, then generate hair.
10383418825325.name: cgwiki - Hair and Fur | Matt Estela

10383418825327.author: Matt Estela
10383418825327.description: Dops aren't sops (obviously), they don't directly model the flow of points through a graph, rather they setup behaviors and relationships. Remember that a sim is all about calculating based on the results of the previous frame, so thats what DOP networks are there to help you setup; a way to set an initial state, then a loop where data flows through, gets to the bottom, is fed into the top again, every frame.
10383418825327.name: cgwiki - Dops (Dynamics and Sim) | Matt Estela

10383418825330.author: Matt Estela
10383418825330.description: The intro tips are a little old, but still give a pretty good overview of what Houdini's about. One of these days I'll do a sweep to update it all for H18..
10383418825330.name: cgwiki - Quicktips | Matt Estela

10383418825331.author: Matt Estela
10383418825331.description: Houdini allows you to build rigid body constraints with polylines. The lines represent the constraints, and the ends are attached to the rigid body objects by name matching. If no name matches, then they get attached to the world.
10383418825331.name: cgwiki - Constraint Networks I | Matt Estela

10383418825332.author: Matt Estela
10383418825332.name: cgwiki - Constraint Networks II | Matt Estela

10383418825333.author: Matt Estela
10383418825333.description: If you're coming from a Maya background, you might wonder what the fuss is about. You might be extra puzzled when people talk about points vs primitives (prims for short), and even more puzzled when verticies (verts) are thrown into discussion too.
10383418825333.name: cgwiki - Points / Vertices / Prims | Matt Estela

10383418825335.author: Matt Estela
10383418825335.description: The solver sop isn't really a sop per-se; its a subnet, but one that lets you setup feedback loops. This gives you access to a range of interesting techniques that'd otherwise be difficult to achieve. Solver sops can be a little unintuitive though so its best to start simple and work up.
10383418825335.name: cgwiki - Solver Sop | Matt Estela

10383418825336.author: Matt Estela
10383418825336.description: The pyro solver isn't too scary once you understand it, and gets amazing results. I found I got a better understanding by building a simple smoke sim first, and gradually adding complexity. There's a few things to do before getting into dops, the first of which is to create a volume.
10383418825336.name: cgwiki - Smoke & Pyro | Matt Estela

10383418825338.author: Matt Estela
10383418825338.description: At it's simplest, rest lets you store the position of geo as an attribute. But lets start from first principles.
10383418825338.name: cgwiki - Rest Attribute | Matt Estela

10383418825339.author: Matt Estela
10383418825339.name: cgwiki - Copy, Stamps, Rotation, HScript, Vex | Matt Estela

10383418825341.author: Mikael Pettersen
10383418825341.description: Intermediate Crowd Tutorial that walks you through every step including Agents, Ragdoll, Kinefx.
10383418825341.name: Sidefx Tutorial - Zombies for Everyone | Mikael Pettersen

10383418825342.author: Robert Magee
10383418825342.description: In this lesson, you will smash a wine glass then slow down time to hold onto the big splash. This effect involves both an RBD simulation for the shattered glass and a fluid simulation for the wine. You will learn how to set up the dynamic network and output the simulations. Visual effect shots often involve a combination of different kinds of dynamic solvers and Houdini's dynamic network is designed to acheive a unified result with these different solvers.
10383418825342.name: Sidefx Tutorial - Smashing Wine Glass | Robert Magee

51864829680514.author: Matt Estela @ CgWiki
51864829680514.description: Delays an animation by number of frames
51864829680514.name: Delay Rig Animation

51864829680515.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680515.description: An overview of the basic rig setup using KineFX.
51864829680515.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - A First Look At KineFX

51864829680516.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680516.description: This video covers a very basic IK/FK system in KineFX.
51864829680516.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX A Simple IK/FK

51864829680517.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680517.description: In this video we create an HDA for the rig and connect the controls so that we can manipulate the rig without the need to select the pose nodes. The customization of the controls is limited at the moment when not using scripting but we can still create an accessible rig.
51864829680517.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX Building The HDA

51864829680518.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680518.description: Recently I was asked about muscle systems in kineFX. There is currently no native implementation of a muscle system in kineFX but as KineFX is part of SOPs it is pretty simple to set up a system.  This was the first implementation that came to mind but I also thought about a meta-ball based system.
51864829680518.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - Experimenting With Muscle Systems In KineFX

51864829680519.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680519.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX A Basic Curve Rig

51864829680520.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680520.description: This is a short examination of very basic IK setups for 3 Bone legs.
51864829680520.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX 3 Bone Legs

51864829680521.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680521.description: KineFX makes it a lot easier to visualise the rig. Here I update the basic Dog-leg rig and discuss some of the problems you will encounter when rigging.
51864829680521.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX Troubleshooting Transforms (Improving the Dog Leg Rig)

51864829680522.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680522.description: Getting your FK bones to match the IK is very important when animating a rig. Here I create a system to achieve this.
51864829680522.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX IK/FKMatching

51864829680523.author: Rebelway
51864829680523.description: In this video tutorial, we'll show you how to create procedural rock textures for environment design inside Houdini for Arnold and Unreal Engine.
51864829680523.name: Masterclass - H18.5 - Procedural Asset Development for Environments in Houdini

51864829680548.author: Yongji Chen
51864829680548.description: How to use volume and COP in houdini to generate wetmap in a solver!
51864829680548.name: Tutorial - H18 - Create wet map based on volume and COP

51864829680549.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680549.description: A basic tutorial on how to use the SOP solver and SOP networks within DOPs to create geometry and constraints on the fly in simulations. Presented in the context of the bullet solver, but generalizes.
51864829680549.name: Tutorial - H17.5 - SOPs in DOPs - Part 1

51864829680550.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680550.description: In part 2, we look at how to spawn fractured geometry into a running simulation, bringing in the geo and constraints at the same time, handling renaming, and avoiding collisions.
51864829680550.name: Tutorial - H17.5 - SOPs in DOPs - Part 2

51864829680551.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680551.description: Dynamic fracturing, from scratch, including breakable constraints and rest-space corrections. Intermediate/Advanced, but paced so anyone can follow along. VEX-heavy and DOPs-heavy.
51864829680551.name: Tutorial - H17.5 - Dynamic Fracturing

51864829680552.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680552.description: In this tutorial I go over a flexible approach for breaking glue constraints in rigid body simulations using arbitrary forces.
51864829680552.name: Tutorial - H18 - Breaking Glue with Forces

51864829680553.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680553.description: In this tutorial, I cover an approach for integrating FLIP and Pyro solvers, allowing for bidirectional interaction between the two simulations in DOPs.
51864829680553.name: Tutorial - H17.5 - FLIP-Pyro Interaction

51864829680554.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680554.description: In this tutorial, I cover a relatively straightforward workflow for emulating fracturing within a FLIP simulation using per-point viscosity. Along the way I cover a bit about shading / uv-ing fluids using the dual rest method, and I close with an alternative approach to the workflow that preserves more of the classic RBD-destruction look.
51864829680554.name: Tutorial - H17.5 - Flip Fracture

51864829680555.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680555.description: In this tutorial I go over a simple but flexible approach for creating and controlling fluid properties in FLIP at the interface between two different types of fluids.
51864829680555.name: Tutorial - H18 - FLIP Interface Reactions

51864829680556.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680556.description: In this tutorial I cover three mini-projects showing some of the ways you can use fiber attributes in Houdini's FEM solver to drive soft-body motion procedurally.
51864829680556.name: Tutorial - H18 - FEM Fibers & Procedural motion

51864829680557.author: Diffuse FX
51864829680557.description: We'll cover a basic version (tearing a flat sheet) from scratch, then I'll go over a few variations to generalize the effect to other kinds of geometry.
51864829680557.name: Tutorial - H17.5 - POP grains tearing effect

51864829680558.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680558.description: The twist controls on the curve solver (in kinefx) are not very good. In this video we look at creating a custom system for rotations.
51864829680558.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX Spine Rotations

51864829680559.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680559.description: In the last video we looked at creating more stable rotations for the  spine in this video we apply them so that they will correctly affect the child objects.
51864829680559.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX Spine Rotations 02 Propagating Transforms

51864829680560.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680560.description: This is a very quick and nasty overview of a reverse foot rig setup in  KineFX. It is bit bare-bones but if does cover a full setup.
51864829680560.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - KineFX A Basic Reverse Foot Setup

51864829680561.author: Brundlethwaite
51864829680561.description: KineFX gives us a far more flexible rigging and export pipeline than the object based rigging system. This system gives us a lot more control but this   means that the initial setup is less intuitive than the old export process.
51864829680561.name: Tutorial - H18.5 - FBX Export

29374032330808.name: 3d coordinates  into NDC camera space

59378995269102.description: Removes points that dont face another object
59378995269102.name: Remove points by direction toward other object

59378995269103.author: Maxime Hacquard
59378995269103.description: In this talk, Maxime will share his experience about starting Houdini for 3D Motion Design and talk about his director point of view about picking an artist for a project.
59378995269103.name: Presentation - Houdini and Motion Graphics | Maxime Hacquard | OFFF HIVE 2021

59378995269104.author: Tim Bolland
59378995269104.description: Heightfields in Houdini work wonderfully well, and can be used for far more than just terrains. Over the past few years we have played around with them in various set-ups, taking advantage of their quick speed and extensive tool-set. My plan will be to show you a few examples, and elaborate on how Heightfields have helped enable some of our more interesting shots.
59378995269104.name: Presentation - Heightfields in Motion | ManvsMachine | OFFF HIVE 2021

59378995269105.author: Will MacNeil
59378995269105.description: Will's talk looks at his weather paintings system, D'istral. Will will go through the process behind acquiring live weather data and using it to create generative images, all within Houdini. This will include a quick look at Python scripting as well as massaging data values and then connecting them a generative art system.
59378995269105.name: Presentation - Painting with Data | Will MacNeil | OFFF HIVE 2021

59378995269106.author: Simon Holmedal
59378995269106.description: A breakdown of Panoply's project for Herradura, covering the unconventional transition techniques.
59378995269106.name: Presentation - Shape Shifting | Panoply | OFFF HIVE 2021

59378995269107.author: Alexa Sirbu
59378995269107.description: From conception to delivery, Houdini is at the core of all XK studio's productions. This presentation will show how Houdini helps in producing a range of visuals for art, fashion, beauty and technology clients.
59378995269107.name: Presentation - XK studio x Houdini | OFFF HIVE 2021

59378995269108.author: Ahmed Gharraph
59378995269108.description: An in-depth look at the process we went through to create two very different creatures for two very different Television shows.
59378995269108.name: Presentation - Stags & Stripes, Creating Photoreal Characters | Framestore | FMX HIVE 2021

59378995269109.author: Mark Fancher
59378995269109.description: In this talk, I'll be presenting a few techniques for creating 'fake liquid' effects in Houdini. By 'fake', I mean non-simulated effects that appear liquid-like in terms of stylized motion design. This is basically volume-building on steroids. I'll be sharing some setups I've created and used in production that lean heavily on the VDB toolset to achieve super flexible control over liquid-like behavior in SOPs.
59378995269109.name: Presentation - Mograph Liquids | Mark Fancher | OFFF HIVE 2021

59378995269110.author: Andreas Weidman
59378995269110.description: The tricks, tips, and lessons learned from our first Solaris production. What to expect, the challenges faced; and the solutions we found while working with variants, instances, animated shaders and much more.
59378995269110.name: Presentation - Workflows from a Solaris Production | Swiss International | FMX HIVE 2021

59378995269111.author: Sarah Forcier
59378995269111.description: Pixar's lead developer of the RenderMan for Houdini plugin, Sarah Forcier, will show where state-of-the-art rendering technology is headed in the upcoming version of RenderMan 24, with updates on XPU, Lama, and other major features in this upcoming release.
59378995269111.name: Presentation - RenderMan 24 - Bringing Powerful New Tools To Houdini | Pixar & 9to3 Animation | FMX HIVE 2021

59378995269112.author: Mike Battcock
59378995269112.description: This talk will be an overview and breakdown of the VFX completed by Time Based Arts for the PlayStation 5  advert 'Play Has No Limits'. The advert is almost entirely CGI and contains a huge number of FX, assets, environments and characters, including a kraken and rock troll!
59378995269112.name: Presentation - Playstation 5 - Play Has No Limits | Time Based Arts | OFFF HIVE 2021

59378995269113.author: Marco Doerner
59378995269113.description: Tune in for a look at the brand new USD pipeline from Rebellion VFX that was used to bring the Evil Genius 2 trailer to life. Aleksandr and Marco talk about their experience on the project from an FX and Lighting point of view.
59378995269113.name: Presentation - A Pipeline from Scratch - Making of the Evil Genius 2 Cinematic Trailer | Rebellion VFX | FMX HIVE 2021

56187691671700.author: Tim Van Helsdingen
56187691671700.description: I was asked to create a demo video utilizing vellum fluids... so naturally I created a digital mojito. In my talk I break down the entire project from start to finish, talk about the issues I ran into, tips and tricks for rendering in karma, and a lot more. Tim Van Helsdingen is a Freelance CG generalist and Houdini FX artist, connoisseur of memes, and lover of cheese. As a freelance artist he gets to make cool 3d stuff for a lot of different people all over the world, and he also gets to teach the stuff he knows on his youtube channel or in presentations such as this.
56187691671700.name: Presentation - Hive - Using Vellum Fluids to Create a Mojito | H19

56187691671701.author: Bishoy Khalifa
56187691671701.description: A preview of the grains statues setup done in H19 and a look at the new vellum upgrades. Bishoy Khalifa is a Lead FX TD at Trend VFX
56187691671701.name: Presentation - Hive - Vellum Grains in Houdini 19 | H19

56187691671702.author: Adam Swaab
56187691671702.description: This short talk will present a sneak peak and first impressions of Karma XPU and MaterialX in Houdini. This is by no means a master class, but a general overview of what's new and exciting about rendering in Houdini 19. We'll also look at how to quickly set up a scene in Solaris, for those uninitiated with the LOPS context. Adam Swaab is a CG Artist and designer. He's been working in the commercial and film industry for over twenty years, primarily specializing in high-end motion graphics.
56187691671702.name: Presentation - Hive - Karma XPU and MaterialX | H19

56187691671703.author: Miguel Perez Senent
56187691671703.description: Going through the new Pyro Tools in Houdini 19
56187691671703.name: Presentation - Hive - Shockwaves Tool in Houdini 19 | H19

56187691671704.author: Joshua Rizzo
56187691671704.description: Houdini 19 has some awesome new toys for Pyro and Volumes. This talk will highlight the process for the Fire Tornado seen in the Sneak Peek, which makes heavy use of the new Volume Deform workflow, showcasing some of the methods behind and to conclude highlighting some challenges and problem solving. Joshua Rizzo is a Junior FX Artist currently in his graduation year at Breda University of Applied Sciences in the Netherlands, studying International Game Architecture and Design. Houdini has been an integral part since he started studying and has quickly become his focus of learning VFX and Technical Art. Joshua enjoys the flexibility of working of Houdini, making learning technicality and visual development very accessible and fun.
56187691671704.name: Presentation - Hive - Fire Tornado in Houdini 19 | H19

56187691671705.author: Attila Torok
56187691671705.description: This part of the presentation will center around the new pyro tools and features in houdini 19, such as the updated pyro workflow, improved volume shading, volume-deformation, axis-force, spark tools and many more. Attila Torok is a London based FX TD working for SideFX. He has started out as a SideFX internship student after which he worked for Double Negative on projects like The Hunger Games: Catching Fire, Godzilla. Before coming back to SideFX he spent 4 years at ILM, where next to a list of movies like Doctor Strange, Avengers: Infinity War, Ready Player One, Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker, he was building and maintaining tools for particle simulations, deformable and tearable rigid body simulations and for pyro used throughout the company.
56187691671705.name: Presentation - Hive - Sexy Pyro | H19

56187691671706.author: Mikael Pettersen
56187691671706.description: There is a staggering amount of cool stuff in Houdini 19 and the the crowd updates might not be the first that comes to mind. They are still very useful though and Mikael is going to walk you through his favourites
56187691671706.name: Presentation - Hive - Houdini 19 Crowds - Shiny New Layers and Meta Power | H19

56187691671707.author: Mihnea Stoica
56187691671707.description: In this session, we will go through the tool set designed for applying secondary animation, like lag, overshoot and ragdoll, on KineFX characters. We will dig through some scenes that we have built to showcase these tools in actions and explain how you could create something similar yourself. The tools that we will be covering today are: secondary motion SOP and the three ragdoll SOPs - ragdoll collision shapes, ragdoll constraint and ragdoll solver.
56187691671707.name: Presentation - Hive - KineFX Secondary Motion Tools | H19

56187691671708.author: Richard C. Thomas
56187691671708.description: A walk through of the PolySlice tool, its development, and how its features can be used to process geometry to create complex patterns that are graphic, organic and technology inspired through practical examples.
56187691671708.name: Presentation - Hive - SideFX Labs PolySlice | H19

56187691671709.author: Attila Torok
56187691671709.description: The presentation will demonstrate the new digital asset creation workflow to help technical artist with they asset management. While the second part of the presentation will cover the new file-cache 2.0 node, and comparing it to the also new labs file-cache workflow.
56187691671709.name: Presentation - Hive - Asset Workflow and File Caching | H19

56187691671710.author: Mai Ao
56187691671710.description: In this talk, Mai will walk you through Houdini 19 and SideFX Labs' newest real-time pyro workflows. Beautiful and fast viewport renders, film-industry-standard ACES color space setups, redesigned visualization and flipbook export tools, our latest compression and shader techniques, all of which work together to bring your real-time pyro effects to the next level, where they can fit naturally within the highly realistic environments of the next-gen games.
56187691671710.name: Presentation - Hive - Real-Time Pyro Workflows - Chasing Photorealism | H19

56187691671711.author: Fianna Wong
56187691671711.description: This presentation will cover how you can do environment concepting using the new Layout LOP and the Layout Asset Gallery in Houdini 19. Primarily, this is geared towards those who want to use Karma and paint assets in their scene, but don't necessarily care about the maximum blinding power of USD.
56187691671711.name: Presentation - Hive - Layout LOP & Layout Asset Gallery | H19

56187691671712.author: Robert Magee
56187691671712.description: When Houdini artists talk, it can seem like they are speaking in their own secret language. In this session, Robert explores how easy it is to understand Houdini-speak in relation to the new Layout, Lookdev and Lighting tools in Solaris while introducing different ways that a node-based procedural workflow can support your rendering workflows. Along the way, you will learn about the different types of nodes, networks and assets that you can create in Solaris and how they all work together.
56187691671712.name: Solaris Workshop - The Secret Language of Solaris | H19

56187691671713.author: Andreas Weidman
56187691671713.description: Simplifying Solaris and USD concepts, together with a peek into real world productions and small studio toolsets.
56187691671713.name: Solaris Workshop - Solaris on Easy Mode | H19

56187691671714.author: Yolanda Charlo
56187691671714.description: In this workshop, we are going to take a closer look at working with materials in Solaris. We will explore the Assign and UnAssign Material LOP, different uses of collections, selection rules, geometry subsets and a quick look at MaterialX
56187691671714.name: Solaris Workshop - Understanding Solaris Materials | H19

56187691671715.author: Chris Rydalch
56187691671715.description: This workshop covers building USD assets in Solaris, using the Component Builder tool-set added in Houdini 19. We'll discuss what USD assets can look like, and how the Component Builder simplifies making good USD assets even for artists new to USD/Solaris. We will also cover how to leverage some of these features down the road, in later stages of a pipeline. Hopefully by the end you will come away with more confidence about USD assets, as well as a better understanding of using the Component Builder in your projects.
56187691671715.name: Solaris Workshop - Creating USD Assets with Component Builder | H19

56187691671716.author: Hannes Reindl & Ben Lutz
56187691671716.description: We will share some more detailed insights about setting up a USD pipeline with Solaris, the choices we faced and our approach to defining the USD hierarchy, composition and implementation with LOPs. How considering some advanced aspects like LIVRPS and the handling of layers in LOPs helped us in defining the USD structure and creating a cleaner Solaris node setup. We will show how we built up our assets using variants, proxies and inherits, layered our shots to achieve a template based workflow and approached render passes. The hip file used for this demonstration will be shared.
56187691671716.name: Solaris Workshop - A Solaris Production Retrospective | H19
